stay.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to remain in a place rather than leave
stay.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Isabel stayed for a year in Paris to study.
stay for a year/ten minutes/a week etc
Stay right there! I’ll be back in a minute.
Why don’t you stay for supper?
stay to dinner/stay for lunch etc
Stay in bed and drink plenty of liquids.
She stayed late to finish the report.
Some of the students stayed after class  (=remained after others had gone) to talk.
stay.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In written English, people often prefer to use remain rather than stay, because it sounds more formal:
Many people opted to remain in their homes.
She remained as his deputy for ten years.
stay.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to continue to be in a particular position, place, or state, without changing
stay.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Rollings will stay as chairman this year.
It was hard to stay awake.
Nine women gained weight, and four stayed the same.
You stay on this road for a mile before turning off.
Most of her boyfriends don’t stay around  (=stay with her) very long.
stay.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: Stay is a linking verb in this meaning This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
They’re just trying to stay alive
I hope we can stay friends
stay.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to live in a place for a short time as a visitor or guest
stay.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: How long are they going to stay?
Did you stay the night at Carolyn’s?
My mother is staying with us this week.
They’re staying in the same hotel.
stay.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: stay
to not leave a place, or to be in a place for a particular period of time
Stay where you are and don’t move.
John only stayed at the party for a couple of hours.
remain
to stay somewhere. In written English, people often prefer to use remain  rather than stay, because it sounds more formal
Some 2,000 protesters remained outside the building and refused to leave.
The judge recommended that he remain in jail for the rest of his life.
linger
to stay in a place a little longer than you need to, because you are enjoying yourself, or because you hope to see someone or something
He lingered outside the lecture hall, hoping for a chance to talk to her.
There are plenty of small cafés where you can linger over a cappuccino.
loiter
to stay in a place not doing anything – used when you think someone is waiting for the chance to do something bad or illegal
The two men had been seen loitering in the area on the day that the car was stolen.
hang around
to stay somewhere not doing anything
There are gangs of boys hanging around on street corners.
I don’t mind hanging around for a few minutes.
The boss doesn’t like being kept hanging around.
stick around
to stay in the same place or situation for a period of time, especially while you are waiting for something to happen or someone to arrive
I decided to stick around and see how it all turned out.
Make up your mind. I’m not going to stick around forever.
stay.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used to tell a dog not to move
stay.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a limited time of living in a place
stay.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: a short stay in the hospital
I met her towards the end of my stay in Los Angeles.
stay.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the stopping or delay of an action because a judge has ordered it
stay of execution (=a delay in punishing someone by killing them)
stay.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: a strong wire or rope used for supporting a ship’s mast
stay.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: a short piece of plastic or wire used to keep a shirt collar stiff
stay.translation[2].note_box[0].sections: During his long stay in the south, he painted only one portrait.
No visa is required for short stays.
Business trips may involve an overnight stay.
Our driver said goodbye and wished us a pleasant stay.
Sally is back at work after a short stay in hospital.
We hope you have a pleasant stay.
He could not be persuaded to extend his stay.
